403.comment:
It's a concept of Complex No. which students used to study in 11th standard in CBSE board and now in ICSE too.It consist of Polar form concept which is used to express complex no. in the form of  trigonometric form.

let x be the angle, and i = square root of -1.
Tan x= (imaginary part/real part) , so we can get our angle I.e "x".
So the polar form will be,
cos x + i sin x 
And it is equal to e^ix which is none other than great and famous Euler's Identity.
Now when "x" is pi radian or 180° so cos 180 = -1 and sin 180 =0.
So e^180i = cos 180 + i sin 180.
So e^180i = -1.
And hence 
e^180i + 1 =0 or -1 + 1 =0.

696.comment:
Still think it's more beautiful with Tau.

Then e^{ix}=cos(x)+i*sin(x) becomes e^{i*Tau} = 1 + 0, or simplified: e^{i*Tau} = 1. 

Which states something rather marvelous, that is; e^{i*Tau} = unity.

It also makes more sense to use tau than pi, since we don't use diameters to define circles, we use the radius (which gives us tau, i.e. circumference/radius). 

It *also* makes trigonometry a heck of a lot easier. Really recommend Viharts video on the topic: 'Pi is (still) wrong'.

732.comment:
For those of you who are confused, Euler's theorem states that for any real number x

e^(i*x) = cos(x) + i*sin(x), given x in our case = Pi and substituting into this equation we obtain
e^(i*Pi) = cos(Pi) + i*sin(Pi), where cos(Pi) = 1 and sin(Pi)=0, therefore
e^(i*Pi) = -1 + 0*i where 0*i is just 0. Rearranging,
e^(i*Pi) +1 = 0

1158.comment:
To an engineer the meaning of  the symbols of mathematics is a real function/action so let us explain this from the point of view of what vision an engineer sees. There is nothing imaginary to an engineer including the square root of (- 1)

e^x=1+1+x/(1*2) + x^2/(1*2*3) ...........  represents the summation of a number of ever vectors all in the same direction and so the growth of a tree, the  growth of money in the bank, the radiation of atomic energy/ explosions,  are all natural functions where the element  added or subtracted is proportional to the  remaining mass.  This is basically a most natural function.
But in nature not everything grows in a straight line  and so engineers have to learn how to represent functions that do not grow in straight lines as branches in a plant or vines to make grapes.   Without going into much detail, the square root of (minus one) or (--1),  from an engineering point of view,  from  the location (1,0) on an X Y plot  one may get to the point represented by (-1,0) (minus one) through the point  (1,0) being rotated in two equal rotations operations of 90 degrees each, while the cube root of (-1)(minuns one) may be obtained through  the position (1,0) passing through three equal angular rotations of 60 degrees each.   This  rotation operation is very useful in engineering and so the square root of ( minus 1) can  be associated with a rotation of 90 degrees in a selected direction, say anticlockwise.  

Now, e^jx= 1+jx +(jx)^2/(1*2) + (jx)^3/(1*2*3+  (jx)^4/(1*2*3*4)...................

It becomes clear that
The first term  1 is a vector which is not rotated.
The second term is a rotated vector by 90 degrees
The third term  is two rotations of 90 degrees bringing it around to 180 degrees
The fourth term is three rotations of 90 degrees bringing it around to 270 degrees
The fifth term is four rotations of 90  degrees bringing it around to 360 degrees
The sixth term will be five rotations of 90 degrees ........................ and so on and on.
Now when x= pi  the summation of all these  rotating vectors come at (-1,0)  where pi originates from the fact that the circumference of a complete circle divided by the diameter is  pi= 3.142 approx. 

(  the even powers produce the vectors falling on the X axis  represent the cosine terms while the others odd powers falling on the Y axis  the sine terms 

The total  engineering picture of all this is that there is a " rotating spiral"  where the trajectory  follows  points that are all located on the X and Y coordinates  so the vector summation of the rotating system is  somewhat like  a Corn's spiral  which ends up falling on the ( -1,0) location hence  e*(j*pi)+1=0

1175.comment:
here's another beautiful number I discovered myself (idk if anyone already mentioned this in the history of math ever but I haven't done my research at the time that I am writing this, so I will proceed)

142857.
why?

multiplied by two, becomes 285714
by three, 428571
by four, 571428
by five, 714285
by six, 857142
but by seven, becomes 999999

anymore than six, with the exceptions of joining the number 0 to the numbers 1-6 to form a two-digit number (e.g., 10, 20, 30, etc.) and multiplying them to 142857, and the special exception of multiplying seven to it (or 70 or any number of digits starting with 7) will result in one of the digits present in 142857 to be missing.

more rules:
the digits present in 142857 will be present in that order when dividing a number non-divisible by 7 once (meaning it will result in a number with decimals, not a whole number) in the resulting decimals. dividing the number with 142857 in its decimals already by 7 once more will result in not seeing the number 142857.


edit:
okay so I did my research and it turns out this number has been discovered by other people.
if you didn't understand my explanation perhaps this might help:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/142,857

1357.comment: I don't agree that it's the most beautiful equation in math, for the sole reason that it is notationally 'wrong' in a sense. It's like defining Euler's number to be e^2 instead of e so that a lot of identities with e and e^x lose their beauty. Pi has unarguably been defined wrongly, as the ratio of the circumference to the diameter of the circle, when it is the RADIUS that characterises the circle. Why are we arbitrarily defining it in terms of twice the radius? If pi was defined correctly, then then this equation would be e^(i pi)=1, which would be the most beautiful equation in math, without having to add in a forced 'under-simplification' (moving the -1 to the left) just so that it doesn't look ugly.

f(x)=x^3-3x^2-24x+17
df/dx=3x^2-6x-24
d^2f/dx^2=6=x-6
d(x) is a local extrema when df/dx=0
3x^2-6x-24=0
x^2-2x-8=0
using the quadratic formula yields x=(2+/-sqrt(4-4*1*-8))/2
x=2/4
x is a local maximum when d^2f/dx^2<0 at x=(df(x)/dx=0)

1774.comment: We have: cos(pi) = -1 and sin(pi) = 0.As we know: exp(i*pi) is the power form of the complex number pi = pi + 0i and cos(pi) + i*sin(pi) is his triangular form so we see that: exp(i*pi) = cos(pi) + i*sin(pi) = -1 + 0 = -1. As a result, exp(i*pi) + 1 = -1 + 1 = 0.

1833.comment:
I understand why that's interesting but beautiful? If you want it to be beautiful, explain it through group theory, where it's not just "Yeh we smushed together 3 crazy numbers and got a normal number huehue", it becomes an empirically intuitive property of numbers, it's the fact that if you rotate the complex plane 90 degrees you can turn i into -1, and if you keep going, it becomes -i, and then +1.
Reach that simple and intuitive understanding, and you got beauty,, this video only shows the narrowest blindest look into the beauty of it.
